DOC.HEAD: Bodies of Servicemen Killed in Panama Begin Arriving at Dover Air Force Base
Eds: UPDATES throughout with 14 more bodies arriving in Dover. No pick up. ^LaserPhoto DV1
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of 18 U.S. servicemen killed in the invasion of Panama were returned Thursday to Dover Air Force Base and honored during a brief planeside ceremony. Shortly before midnight, the remains of 13 soldiers and one Marine arrived on a C5 Galaxy in windy, 7-degree weather. Secretary of the Army Michael P.W. Stone said the servicemen returned ``to a nation that is grateful, both for their duty in the cause of liberty, and above all, for their sacrifice'' in defense of demoracy. Earlier Thursday, the bodies of four U.S. Navy men killed during the invasion of Panama were returned to the base and also honored during a brief planeside ceremony. ``The four brave men we mourn here today now rest in the quiet arms of a grateful nation and a loving God,'' said Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III said. ``These magnificent young men have made the greatest sacrifices for us all.'' Garrett said the four men returned to ``our embrace'' having fought for the liberty and dignity that Americans enjoy. Cmdr. Bob Prucha, a Navy spokesman, said the four were members of the Navy special operations unit known as the SEALS. They died leading the assault on Tortilla Air Field in Panama. Prucha did not know if they were killed at the field or died later from wounds suffered in the attack. ``All we can do is honor their memory by never forgetting that our lives, under the banner of democracy, have been further protected with their deaths,'' Garrett said. The four dead were identified as Boatswain's Mate 1st Class Christopher Tilghman, 30, of Kailua, Hawaii; Lt. j.g. John P. Connors, 25, of Arlington, Mass.; Chief Engineman Donald L. McFaul, 32, of San Diego, Calif.; and Torpedoman's mate Second Class Issac G. Rodriguez III, 24, of Los Angeles. All four were stationed at the Naval Amphibious Base in Little Creek, Va., near Norfolk. The base mortuary opened in 1968 and has handled the remains of servicemen killed in the Vietnam War, Marines killed in a terrorist bombing of their headquarters in Beirut and the remains of Navy men killed in the USS Iowa explosion.
